timeframe.label: Timeframe:
timeframe.tooltip:
Chart Timeframe Selector

1) WHAT IT IS:
Select the time period represented by each candlestick on the chart.
1m = 1-minute candles, 1d = daily candles, etc.

Each timeframe represents a different granularity of price action:
- Higher timeframes (4h, 1d) = bigger picture, less noise
- Lower timeframes (1m, 5m) = detailed view, more noise

2) HOW AND WHEN TO USE:

When to use different timeframes:
- Scalping: 1m, 5m (trades lasting 5-60 minutes)
- Day trading: 15m, 30m, 1h (trades within the same day)
- Swing trading: 4h, 1d (trades lasting days to weeks)
- Position trading: 1d, 1w (trades lasting weeks to months)

How to use (Multi-timeframe analysis):
1. Start with higher timeframe (1d) to identify major trend
2. Drop to medium timeframe (1h) to find entry zones
3. Use lower timeframe (15m) for precise entry timing

Relevance by strategy:
- Scalping: CRITICAL - must use 1m/5m for entries
- Day trading: IMPORTANT - 15m/1h is your decision timeframe
- Swing trading: MODERATE - 4h/1d for entries, lower TF for precision
- Position trading: LOW - 1d/1w sufficient, lower TF unnecessary

3) WHY TO USE IT:
- See the same market at different time scales
- Align your strategy with appropriate granularity
- Avoid trading against the higher timeframe trend (e.g., don't short on 15m if 1d is strong uptrend)
- Multi-timeframe confluence increases probability of success
- Match timeframe to your trading style and available time

4) EFFECTS:

4.1) LOW TIMEFRAMES (1m, 5m):

Behavior:
- Each candle forms very quickly (1-5 minutes)
- Extremely detailed price action visible
- Every small move captured
- High frequency of signals

Advantages:
- Maximum precision for scalping entries
- Catch micro-patterns and quick reversals
- Perfect for intraday momentum trading
- See exact price levels where orders execute

Disadvantages:
- Very HIGH NOISE - many false signals
- Requires constant monitoring (can't step away)
- Spread costs significant on small moves
- Whipsaws and stop hunts common
- Stressful and time-consuming

When to use:
- Scalping strategies (5-15 minute holds)
- Precise entry timing within larger setup
- Day trading during high volatility sessions
- When you can actively monitor for hours

4.2) MEDIUM TIMEFRAMES (15m, 30m, 1h):

Behavior:
- Balanced view of price action
- Filters out most micro-noise
- Patterns form over hours
- Moderate frequency of signals

Advantages:
- OPTIMAL balance noise vs signal
- Reliable patterns (3+ candles = hours of confirmation)
- Good for part-time traders (check every hour)
- Widely followed by institutions (support/resistance respected)
- Lifestyle-friendly (not glued to screen)

Disadvantages:
- Slower reaction to news events (compared to 1m/5m)
- Larger stop losses needed (more pips)
- Fewer opportunities (1-2 setups per day vs 10+ on 1m)
- May miss very fast intraday moves

When to use:
- Day trading (trades lasting 1-8 hours)
- Short-term swing trading (overnight to 3 days)
- PRIMARY timeframe for most retail traders
- When checking chart 1-3 times per hour is feasible

4.3) HIGH TIMEFRAMES (4h, 1d, 1w):

Behavior:
- Big picture view of market
- Very smooth trends, minimal noise
- Patterns develop over days/weeks
- Low frequency of signals

Advantages:
- MAXIMUM RELIABILITY - patterns proven over days
- Major levels highly respected by institutions
- Check ONCE per day (or even weekly)
- Perfect for busy people with day jobs
- Low stress, no need for constant monitoring

Disadvantages:
- VERY SLOW to react (4 hours per candle on 4h chart!)
- Wide stop losses required (50-200 pips)
- Very few opportunities (1-2 setups per month)
- Requires large account (wide stops = more capital)
- Boring for active traders

When to use:
- Swing trading (holds lasting 3-30 days)
- Position trading (weeks to months)
- Trend identification for lower timeframe entries
- When you can only check markets once per day
- When you want lifestyle freedom

5) TYPICAL RANGE / DEFAULT VALUES:

- Minimum: 1m (highest granularity available)
- BEGINNER DEFAULT: 1h (best balance for learning)
- SCALPER DEFAULT: 5m (detailed but not too noisy)
- DAY TRADER DEFAULT: 15m or 1h
- SWING TRADER DEFAULT: 4h or 1d
- POSITION TRADER DEFAULT: 1d or 1w
- Maximum: 1M (monthly, rarely used)

Usage distribution:
- Beginners: 80% should start with 1h timeframe
- Intermediate: 40% use 15m-1h, 40% use 4h-1d, 20% use 1m-5m
- Advanced: Spread across all timeframes based on strategy

Recommendation by experience:
- Beginner: Start with 1h ONLY for first 6 months (master one timeframe)
- Intermediate: Add 4h (trend filter) and 15m (entry timing)
- Advanced: Full multi-timeframe analysis (1d → 4h → 1h → 15m)

6) ADDITIONAL NOTES / BEST PRACTICES:

Multi-timeframe workflow (THE RIGHT WAY):
1. Start on Daily (1d): What's the major trend? Up, down, or range?
2. Drop to 4H: Confirm trend, identify swing structure
3. Drop to 1H: Find entry setups aligned with 4H/Daily trend
4. Drop to 15m: Precise entry point (breakout, pullback, etc.)

Common mistakes to AVOID:
- Trading lower TF against higher TF trend (fighting the trend = lose)
- Using only 1 timeframe (missing big picture)
- Too many timeframes (analysis paralysis, conflicting signals)
- Switching timeframes randomly (lack of consistency)

Optimal timeframe combinations:
- Scalping: 5m (primary) + 15m (trend filter)
- Day trading: 15m (primary) + 1h (trend) + 5m (entry)
- Swing trading: 4h (primary) + 1d (trend) + 1h (entry)
- Position: 1d (primary) + 1w (trend) + 4h (entry)

How ForexGPT uses timeframes:
- Indicators calculated on ALL timeframes simultaneously
- Multi-timeframe ensemble model combines predictions from 6 timeframes
- Regime detection uses 4h and 1d for macro trend
- Signals generated on 1h, refined on 15m for entry

Keyboard shortcuts:
- Ctrl+Up: Next higher timeframe
- Ctrl+Down: Next lower timeframe
- Ctrl+1 through Ctrl+9: Jump to specific timeframes

symbol.label: Symbol:
symbol.tooltip:
Symbol Selector

1) WHAT IT IS:
Choose which currency pair (or financial instrument) to display and analyze.
Symbols formatted as BASE/QUOTE (e.g., EUR/USD = Euro vs US Dollar).

Example: EUR/USD = 1.0850 means 1 Euro = 1.0850 US Dollars

2) HOW AND WHEN TO USE:

When to trade different symbols:
- EUR/USD: Best during London/NY sessions (13:00-22:00 GMT)
- USD/JPY: Best during Tokyo/NY sessions (00:00-09:00, 13:00-22:00 GMT)
- GBP/USD: Best during London session (07:00-16:00 GMT)
- AUD/USD: Best during Sydney/Asian session (22:00-08:00 GMT)

How to use:
- Click dropdown to see all available symbols
- Type first letters to quick-search (e.g., "EU" finds EUR/USD)
- Select symbol to load chart and data
- Right-click for advanced options (add to watchlist, etc.)

Relevance by experience:
- Beginner: Trade ONLY EUR/USD for first 6-12 months (master ONE pair)
- Intermediate: Add 1-2 more majors (GBP/USD, USD/JPY)
- Advanced: 5-8 pairs including crosses, correlation-aware

3) WHY TO USE IT:
- Access different markets and opportunities
- Diversification (don't put all trades in one pair)
- Correlation analysis (EUR/USD and GBP/USD move together)
- Find the pair that's moving (opportunity scanning)
- Each pair has unique characteristics (volatility, spread, behavior)

4) EFFECTS:

4.1) MAJOR PAIRS (Tight spreads, high liquidity):

EUR/USD (Euro vs US Dollar):
- Most traded pair globally (~30% of FX volume)
- Spread: 0.0-1.0 pips (tightest available)
- Volatility: MEDIUM (50-100 pips/day)
- Best for: Beginners, scalping, technical analysis

Advantages:
- Tightest spreads (lowest cost)
- Highest liquidity (instant fills, no slippage)
- Smooth trends, respects technical levels
- Most educational resources available

Disadvantages:
- Can be slow during Asian session
- News-driven (ECB and Fed announcements cause spikes)

When to trade:
- London/NY overlap (13:00-17:00 GMT) - BEST
- European session (07:00-16:00 GMT) - Good
- Asian session (22:00-08:00 GMT) - Slow

GBP/USD (British Pound vs US Dollar - "The Cable"):
- 2nd most popular major
- Spread: 1-3 pips
- Volatility: HIGH (100-200 pips/day)
- Best for: Experienced traders (wild swings)

Advantages:
- High volatility = big profit potential
- Strong trends when it moves
- Active during London session

Disadvantages:
- Sharp reversals (can whipsaw stops)
- Brexit news causes extreme volatility
- Higher spread than EUR/USD
- Requires wider stops (50-100 pips)

When to trade:
- London session (07:00-16:00 GMT) - BEST
- Avoid during major UK news (can spike 50+ pips instantly)

4.2) MINOR PAIRS (Moderate spreads, good liquidity):

EUR/GBP (Euro vs British Pound):
- European cross (no USD)
- Spread: 1.5-3 pips
- Volatility: LOW (30-60 pips/day)
- Best for: Range trading

Advantages:
- Mean-reverting (tends to stay in range)
- Predictable behavior
- Less affected by USD news

Disadvantages:
- Rarely trends (boring for trend traders)
- Lower volatility = smaller profit potential

When to use:
- When both EUR and GBP have clear directional bias
- Range trading strategies (buy support, sell resistance)

4.3) EXOTIC PAIRS (Wide spreads, low liquidity - CAUTION):

EUR/TRY, USD/MXN, USD/ZAR:
- Emerging market currencies
- Spread: 10-100+ pips (!)
- Volatility: EXTREME
- Best for: Advanced traders ONLY

Advantages:
- NONE for most traders (avoid these)

Disadvantages:
- Extremely wide spreads (cost prohibitive)
- Low liquidity (slippage, gaps, poor fills)
- High risk of flash crashes
- Broker manipulation more common
- Overnight gaps of 100-500 pips possible

When to use:
- Almost NEVER (unless you're expert in emerging markets)
- Requires massive stop losses (500-1000 pips)

5) TYPICAL RANGE / DEFAULT VALUES:

- DEFAULT for beginners: EUR/USD (start here, master it)
- DEFAULT for scalpers: EUR/USD or GBP/USD (tight spreads or high volatility)
- DEFAULT for day traders: EUR/USD, GBP/USD, USD/JPY (choose 2-3)
- DEFAULT for swing traders: Any major pair based on setup

Number of pairs to trade:
- Beginner: 1 pair only (EUR/USD recommended)
- Intermediate: 2-4 major pairs
- Advanced: 5-8 pairs including crosses

Usage distribution:
- 60% of traders primarily trade EUR/USD
- 20% primarily GBP/USD
- 10% USD/JPY
- 10% other pairs

6) ADDITIONAL NOTES / BEST PRACTICES:

Pair correlations (IMPORTANT for risk management):
- EUR/USD and USD/CHF: -95% correlation (nearly perfect inverse)
- EUR/USD and GBP/USD: +80% correlation (move together)
- AUD/USD and NZD/USD: +85% correlation (both commodity currencies)

DON'T trade correlated pairs simultaneously:
- EUR/USD long + USD/CHF long = positions cancel out (waste spread)
- EUR/USD long + GBP/USD long = DOUBLE exposure (2× risk if wrong)

DO trade for diversification:
- EUR/USD long + USD/JPY short = uncorrelated (true diversification)

Session optimization:
- Asian (22:00-08:00 GMT): USD/JPY, AUD/USD, NZD/USD
- European (07:00-16:00 GMT): EUR/USD, GBP/USD, EUR/GBP
- NY (13:00-22:00 GMT): All USD pairs
- OVERLAP (13:00-17:00 GMT): BEST time, all majors active

How ForexGPT handles symbols:
- Each symbol has independent trained models
- Correlation matrix updated real-time
- Portfolio risk calculated across all positions
- Alert when opening correlated positions (>80% correlation)

Keyboard shortcuts:
- Ctrl+S: Open symbol selector
- Type letters: Quick search ("GBP" finds GBP/USD)
- Ctrl+→/←: Cycle through watchlist

model_name.label: Model Name:
model_name.tooltip:
Model Name (Optional Custom Name)

1) WHAT IT IS:
Custom name for the trained model file that will be saved.
If left empty, name is auto-generated from features (e.g., "EUR_USD_1h_ridge_ATR_RSI_MACD_20250108").

Example: "my_eurusd_scalping_model_v2" or "production_swing_gbpusd"

2) HOW AND WHEN TO USE:

When to set custom name:
- Production models you'll use for real trading
- A/B testing (e.g., "model_A_conservative" vs "model_B_aggressive")
- Versioning ("v1", "v2", "v3" as you iterate)
- Organizing multiple strategies

When to leave empty (auto-generate):
- Quick experiments and testing
- Don't care about the name
- Want descriptive name based on features

How to use:
- Type any name (letters, numbers, underscore, dash allowed)
- Avoid special characters (/, \, *, ?, <, >, |)
- Keep under 50 characters for readability

3) WHY TO USE IT:
- Easy identification of models later
- Organize models by strategy/version
- Professional workflow ("production_v3" vs random auto-name)
- A/B testing and comparison
- Team collaboration (everyone knows which model is which)

4) EFFECTS:

4.1) EMPTY (Auto-generate name):

Behavior:
- System generates name from: symbol_timeframe_algorithm_features_date
- Example: "EURUSD_1h_ridge_ATR_RSI_MACD_Bollinger_20250108_143022"
- Very long but descriptive name

Advantages:
- FULLY descriptive (you know exactly what's in the model)
- No thinking required
- Never conflicts (timestamp unique)
- Good for experiments

Disadvantages:
- Long and ugly names
- Hard to remember
- Not professional for production

When to use:
- Quick tests and experiments
- Throwaway models
- Learning phase

4.2) CUSTOM NAME SET:

Behavior:
- Model saved with your custom name
- Example: "production_eurusd_v3"
- Metadata still contains all features info

Advantages:
- Clean, professional names
- Easy to remember and reference
- Good for production deployment
- Version control
- Team-friendly

Disadvantages:
- Need to track what features are in each version
- Risk of name conflicts (if not careful with versioning)
- Requires discipline (good naming convention)

When to use:
- Production models
- Models you'll keep and use long-term
- A/B testing
- Professional workflow

5) TYPICAL RANGE / DEFAULT VALUES:

- DEFAULT: Empty (auto-generate)
- Most users: 70% leave empty, 30% use custom names
- Production use: 90% use custom names

Recommended naming convention:
- Format: "[environment]_[symbol]_[strategy]_v[version]"
- Examples:
  * "prod_eurusd_scalp_v3"
  * "test_gbpusd_swing_v1"
  * "paper_usdjpy_trend_v2"

6) ADDITIONAL NOTES / BEST PRACTICES:

Naming conventions for teams:
- Include environment: prod, test, dev, paper
- Include symbol: eurusd, gbpusd (no slash)
- Include strategy type: scalp, swing, trend
- Include version: v1, v2, v3
- Optional: Include date: 20250108

Examples:
- "prod_eurusd_scalp_v3_20250108" (production scalping model v3)
- "test_gbpusd_swing_v1" (test swing trading model)
- "research_multi_symbol_ensemble_v2" (research multi-pair model)

DO NOT use:
- Spaces (use underscore instead)
- Special characters (/, \, *, ?, etc.)
- Very long names (>50 chars hard to read)

Version control:
- Always increment version when retraining
- Keep old versions for rollback
- Document what changed in each version

How ForexGPT uses model names:
- Saved to database (model_metadata table)
- File saved as: artifacts/{model_name}.pkl
- Searchable in model selection dropdowns
- Displayed in backtest results

timeframe.tooltip: [SAME AS CHART.TIMEFRAME.TOOLTIP - Training uses same timeframe concept]

days.label: Days:
days.tooltip:
Days History - Training Dataset Size

1) WHAT IT IS:
Number of historical days to include in the training dataset.
Determines how much past data the model will learn from.

Example: 7 days on 1m timeframe = ~10,080 samples (7 × 24 × 60)
         30 days on 1h timeframe = ~720 samples (30 × 24)

Formula: Total samples ≈ days × (1440 / timeframe_minutes)

2) HOW AND WHEN TO USE:

When to use MORE days (90-365+):
- Production models (need best generalization)
- When you have time for long training (hours)
- Capturing seasonal patterns and cycles
- Stable markets with long-term patterns
- Models you'll use for real money

When to use FEWER days (1-30):
- Quick experiments and prototyping
- Testing new features or algorithms
- Fast iteration during research
- Very recent market regime (only want latest behavior)
- Limited computational resources

How to choose:
- Rule of thumb: At least 1000 samples per feature
- Example: 50 features × 20 samples = 1000 min samples
- On 1m TF: 1000 samples = ~17 hours ≈ 1 day minimum
- On 1h TF: 1000 samples = ~42 days minimum

Relevance by use case:
- Scalping (1m-5m): 7-30 days sufficient (capture recent patterns)
- Day trading (15m-1h): 30-90 days recommended
- Swing trading (4h-1d): 90-365 days optimal
- Research/production: 180-730 days (1-2 years)

3) WHY TO USE IT:
- Control train/test balance (more data = better generalization)
- Capture enough market conditions (trending, ranging, volatile, calm)
- Seasonal patterns (need ≥365 days for yearly cycles)
- Prevent overfitting (too little data = model memorizes noise)
- Statistical significance (more samples = more reliable metrics)

4) EFFECTS:

4.1) VERY LOW (1-3 days):

Behavior:
- Only most recent 1-3 days used for training
- Very small dataset (1,440-4,320 samples on 1m)
- Training completes in seconds

Advantages:
- EXTREMELY FAST training (seconds)
- Tests new ideas instantly
- Only recent market behavior (if regime just changed)
- Low memory usage
- Quick iteration cycle

Disadvantages:
- HIGH OVERFITTING RISK (model memorizes specific recent patterns)
- No seasonal/cyclical patterns captured
- Unstable metrics (small sample = high variance)
- Poor generalization (fails on unseen conditions)
- Not suitable for production

When to use:
- Quick prototyping only
- Testing if code works
- Debugging new features
- NEVER for production trading

Typical results:
- Training accuracy: 70-90% (looks great!)
- Out-of-sample accuracy: 45-55% (disaster - worse than random)
- Model fails within hours/days of deployment

4.2) LOW (7-30 days):

Behavior:
- 1-4 weeks of historical data
- Moderate dataset size (10K-43K samples on 1m)
- Training time: 30 seconds to 5 minutes (Ridge/Lasso)

Advantages:
- FAST training (minutes for most algorithms)
- Captures recent 1-month market regime
- Sufficient for initial experiments
- Good for models you'll retrain frequently (daily/weekly)
- Balances speed and quality

Disadvantages:
- Limited market conditions captured (may miss volatility extremes)
- No long-term patterns (seasonal, cycles)
- Still some overfitting risk
- Walk-forward validation limited (not enough out-of-sample data)

When to use:
- DEFAULT for beginners (good starting point)
- Algorithms you'll retrain frequently
- When training time matters (minutes not hours)
- Markets with fast regime changes (crypto)

Typical results:
- Training accuracy: 60-70%
- Out-of-sample accuracy: 52-58% (decent edge)
- Model useful for 1-4 weeks before retraining needed

4.3) MEDIUM (30-90 days):

Behavior:
- 1-3 months of historical data
- Large dataset (43K-130K samples on 1m)
- Training time: 2-15 minutes (Ridge/Lasso), 10-60 minutes (RF/XGBoost)

Advantages:
- GOOD GENERALIZATION (multiple market conditions)
- Captures 3-month trends and corrections
- Sufficient walk-forward validation data
- Production-quality for short-term strategies
- Balances quality and training time

Disadvantages:
- Longer training time (5-60 minutes)
- May include outdated regime (if market changed)
- Still no full seasonal cycles

When to use:
- RECOMMENDED for day trading models
- Production models for strategies <1 month hold
- When you have 10-60 minutes for training
- Stable markets (forex majors)

Typical results:
- Training accuracy: 58-65%
- Out-of-sample accuracy: 54-60% (solid edge)
- Model useful for 1-3 months

4.4) HIGH (90-180 days):

Behavior:
- 3-6 months of historical data
- Very large dataset (130K-260K samples on 1m)
- Training time: 5-30 minutes (Ridge/Lasso), 30 minutes-2 hours (RF/XGBoost/LightGBM)

Advantages:
- EXCELLENT generalization
- Captures multiple trend cycles
- Robust to regime changes
- High-quality walk-forward validation (3-6 month out-of-sample)
- Near-seasonal coverage (approaching 1 year)

Disadvantages:
- SLOW training (30 min to 2 hours)
- May dilute recent patterns if market changed recently
- High memory usage (GB RAM for complex models)

When to use:
- Production models for serious trading
- Swing trading strategies (multi-day holds)
- When training overnight is acceptable
- Capturing quarterly patterns

Typical results:
- Training accuracy: 56-62%
- Out-of-sample accuracy: 54-59% (reliable edge)
- Model useful for 3-6 months

4.5) VERY HIGH (365-730+ days):

Behavior:
- 1-2 years of historical data
- Massive dataset (525K-1M+ samples on 1m)
- Training time: 15 minutes-1 hour (Ridge/Lasso), 1-8 hours (RF/XGBoost), DAYS (neural networks)

Advantages:
- MAXIMUM generalization
- Full seasonal cycles captured (12-month patterns)
- All market conditions (bull, bear, sideways, volatile, calm)
- Institutional-quality backtesting
- Most robust to regime changes

Disadvantages:
- VERY SLOW training (hours to days)
- May include irrelevant old data (market structure changed)
- Requires powerful computer (high RAM, GPU recommended)
- Potential concept drift (2-year-old patterns may not apply now)

When to use:
- Research and PhD-level work
- Position trading (multi-month holds)
- When you need maximum confidence
- Training models you'll use for years
- Institutional/fund deployment

Typical results:
- Training accuracy: 54-58%
- Out-of-sample accuracy: 53-57% (conservative but reliable)
- Model useful for 6-12 months (very stable)

5) TYPICAL RANGE / DEFAULT VALUES:

- Minimum: 1 day (only for testing code, never production)
- BEGINNER DEFAULT: 7 days (fast iteration, learn quickly)
- INTERMEDIATE DEFAULT: 30 days (balanced)
- ADVANCED DEFAULT: 90 days (production quality)
- PROFESSIONAL DEFAULT: 180-365 days (institutional quality)
- Maximum: 3650 days (10 years, rarely useful - concept drift)

Distribution by experience:
- Beginners: 80% use 7 days, 15% use 30 days, 5% use 90+
- Intermediate: 30% use 7-30 days, 50% use 30-90 days, 20% use 90+
- Advanced: 10% use <30 days, 40% use 30-90 days, 50% use 90-365 days

Distribution by timeframe:
- 1m TF: 7-30 days typical (enough samples, recent patterns)
- 5m-15m TF: 14-60 days typical
- 1h TF: 60-180 days typical (need more calendar days for same sample count)
- 4h-1d TF: 180-730 days typical (each sample is 4h or 1 day!)

Rule of thumb:
- Aim for 5,000-50,000 samples total
- Calculate: samples = days × (1440 / timeframe_minutes)
- Example 1m: 7 days = 10,080 samples ✓
- Example 1h: 7 days = 168 samples ✗ (too few!)
- Example 1h: 90 days = 2,160 samples ✓

6) ADDITIONAL NOTES / BEST PRACTICES:

Calculating required days:
- Minimum samples needed: 1000 samples per feature
- Example: 50 features = 50,000 samples minimum
- On 1m: 50,000 / 1440 ≈ 35 days minimum
- On 1h: 50,000 / 24 ≈ 2,083 days (5.7 years!) - reduce features!

Concept drift consideration:
- Markets change over time (2008 crisis vs 2020 COVID vs 2023 AI era)
- Very old data may hurt more than help
- Recommendation: Use 1-2 years maximum for most models
- Exception: If you're specifically modeling long-term cycles

Memory requirements:
- 1 day 1m data ≈ 1-5 MB (raw OHLCV)
- 1 day 1m data with 100 features ≈ 50-200 MB (in memory)
- 365 days with 100 features ≈ 18-73 GB RAM (!)
- Solution: Use fewer features or higher timeframes

Training time estimates (Ridge regression baseline):
- 7 days: 10 seconds
- 30 days: 30 seconds
- 90 days: 2 minutes
- 180 days: 5 minutes
- 365 days: 15 minutes

(Random Forest 10× slower, XGBoost 5× slower, Neural Networks 100× slower)

Retraining frequency:
- 7 days model: Retrain weekly
- 30 days model: Retrain monthly
- 90 days model: Retrain quarterly
- 365 days model: Retrain 1-2× per year

Interaction with other parameters:
- More days + more features = VERY SLOW (exponential time)
- More days + walk-forward validation = need even MORE days
  (Example: 90 days with 30-day out-of-sample = need 120 days total)
- More days + genetic optimization = EXTREMELY SLOW (days × generations × population)

How ForexGPT uses days parameter:
- Queries database: SELECT * FROM bars WHERE ts_utc >= (now - days)
- Splits into train/test (default 80/20)
- Walk-forward validation uses rolling windows within this period
- Artifacts saved with training period in metadata
